title: Using BiVariAn
text: Suppose want start analysis dataset large number variables. Typically, run normality tests, mean writing one line code every variable. example, use penguins dataset available palmerpenguins package. inspect dataset 8 variables 344 observations. Among variables 5 numeric variables (one representing years), mean writing normality test code . advanced users might consider writing loop using helper functions lapply evaluate variables list (similar approaches). BiVariAn can solve problem (improve display results) using auto_shapiro_raw function. Variable p_shapiro Normality bill_len <0.001* Non-normal bill_dep <0.001* Non-normal flipper_len <0.001* Non-normal body_mass <0.001* Non-normal year <0.001* Non-normal want data frame instead flextable? can flextableformat argument (used functions). checking normality, next natural step apply bivariate tests, write separate code test. example, wanted compare variables across sexes, write something like every variable. Note normality analysis showed non normal distribution, ideally stage apply parametric tests. now, continue needed perform t test, illustrate workflow. every variable quickly becomes iterative repetitive process, addition need write separate code report mean differences corresponding tests. BiVariAn can avoid using continuous_2g function. Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Levene P_T_Test Var_Equal P_Mann_Whitney Diff_Means CI_Lower CI_Upper Significant_test bill_len <0.001* 0.09 <0.001* true <0.001* -3.76 -4.87 -2.65 Mann-W-U test bill_dep <0.001* 0.69 <0.001* true <0.001* -1.47 -1.86 -1.07 Mann-W-U test flipper_len <0.001* 0.04 <0.001* false <0.001* -7.14 -10.06 -4.22 Mann-W-U test body_mass <0.001* 0.01 <0.001* false <0.001* -683.41 -840.58 -526.25 Mann-W-U test year <0.001* 1.00 0.99323 true 0.99373 0.00 -0.17 0.18 None Similarly, can use flextableformat argument obtain data frame. However, can also add labels variables using table1::label() function table1 package. obtain nicely labeled table. Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Levene P_T_Test Var_Equal P_Mann_Whitney Diff_Means CI_Lower CI_Upper Significant_test Bill length <0.001* 0.09 <0.001* true <0.001* -3.76 -4.87 -2.65 Mann-W-U test Bill depth <0.001* 0.69 <0.001* true <0.001* -1.47 -1.86 -1.07 Mann-W-U test flipper_len <0.001* 0.04 <0.001* false <0.001* -7.14 -10.06 -4.22 Mann-W-U test body_mass <0.001* 0.01 <0.001* false <0.001* -683.41 -840.58 -526.25 Mann-W-U test year <0.001* 1.00 0.99323 true 0.99373 0.00 -0.17 0.18 None want title row indicates grouping variable? can add caption argument. Sex Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Levene P_T_Test Var_Equal P_Mann_Whitney Diff_Means CI_Lower CI_Upper Significant_test Bill length <0.001* 0.09 <0.001* true <0.001* -3.76 -4.87 -2.65 Mann-W-U test Bill depth <0.001* 0.69 <0.001* true <0.001* -1.47 -1.86 -1.07 Mann-W-U test flipper_len <0.001* 0.04 <0.001* false <0.001* -7.14 -10.06 -4.22 Mann-W-U test body_mass <0.001* 0.01 <0.001* false <0.001* -683.41 -840.58 -526.25 Mann-W-U test year <0.001* 1.00 0.99323 true 0.99373 0.00 -0.17 0.18 None Important use caption argument mandatory flextableformat TRUE; otherwise error raised. next step create graphical representations. , want use ggplot2 write separate code every plot (implies multiple lines code can become tedious want extensive customization). Let us create boxplot represent comparison flipper_len across sex variable.  Repeating every variable implies multiple lines code. reason, auto_bp_cont function can help streamline workflow. simply call function store output object. object list, can select specific plot want display include report.  remember, previously assigned labels using table1::label(). good news labels can also used plots.  point everything need build report. special mention, useful helper functions regression analysis. example, step_bw_p function helps tedious iterative process simplifying regression models stepwise backward selection based p value threshold, step_bw_firth function performs process models fitted logistf::logistf(). fit model dataset, obtain something like : practice, removes need manually perform three backward selection steps (otherwise require typing full model time using helpers reformulate). can also store output object:
code: data(penguins)  dat <- penguins shapiro.test(dat$bill_len) #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  dat$bill_len #> W = 0.97485, p-value = 1.12e-05 cont_var <- c("bill_len", "bill_dep", "flipper_len", "body_mass")  lapply(dat[cont_var], function(x) shapiro.test(x)) #> $bill_len #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.97485, p-value = 1.12e-05 #>  #>  #> $bill_dep #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.97258, p-value = 4.419e-06 #>  #>  #> $flipper_len #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.95155, p-value = 3.54e-09 #>  #>  #> $body_mass #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.95921, p-value = 3.679e-08 auto_shapiro_raw(data = dat) shapirores <- auto_shapiro_raw(   data = dat,    flextableformat = FALSE )  shapirores #>                Variable p_shapiro  Normality #> bill_len       bill_len   <0.001* Non-normal #> bill_dep       bill_dep   <0.001* Non-normal #> flipper_len flipper_len   <0.001* Non-normal #> body_mass     body_mass   <0.001* Non-normal #> year               year   <0.001* Non-normal # First we would evaluate homoscedasticity car::leveneTest(   dat$bill_len,    group = dat$sex,   center = "median" ) #> Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = "median") #>        Df F value  Pr(>F)   #> group   1  2.8244 0.09378 . #>       331 148.78, df = 341, p-value < 2.2e-16 #> alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  43.34125 44.50261 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x  #>  43.92193 continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex" ) continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex",   flextableformat = FALSE ) #>      Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Levene P_T_Test Var_Equal P_Mann_Whitney #> 1    bill_len         <0.001*  0.09378  <0.001*      TRUE        <0.001* #> 2    bill_dep         <0.001*  0.68955  <0.001*      TRUE        <0.001* #> 3 flipper_len         <0.001* Diff_Means   CI_Lower   CI_Upper Significant_test #> 1   -3.75779   -4.86656   -2.64903    Mann-W-U test #> 2   -1.46562   -1.86021   -1.07103    Mann-W-U test #> 3   -7.14232  -10.06481   -4.21982 are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     units, units<-  table1::label(dat$sex)        <- "Sex" table1::label(dat$bill_len)   <- "Bill length" table1::label(dat$bill_dep)   <- "Bill depth" continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex" ) continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex",   caption = TRUE ) library(tidyr) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following %>%    drop_na(sex) # We remove the NAs from the sex variable  ggplot(   data = dat_comp,   mapping = aes(     x = sex,     y = flipper_len   ) ) +    geom_boxplot() +    labs(     x = "Sex",     y = "Flipper length"   ) +    theme_classic() graphs <- auto_bp_cont(   data = dat_comp,    groupvar = "sex" )  graphs$flipper_len table1::label(dat_comp$sex)         <- "Sex" code: shapiro.test(dat$bill_len) #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  dat$bill_len #> W = 0.97485, p-value = 1.12e-05 cont_var <- c("bill_len", "bill_dep", "flipper_len", "body_mass")  lapply(dat[cont_var], function(x) shapiro.test(x)) #> $bill_len #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.97485, p-value = 1.12e-05 #>  #>  #> $bill_dep #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.97258, p-value = 4.419e-06 #>  #>  #> $flipper_len #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.95155, p-value = 3.54e-09 #>  #>  #> $body_mass #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  x #> W = 0.95921, p-value = 3.679e-08 auto_shapiro_raw(data = dat) shapirores <- auto_shapiro_raw(   data = dat,    flextableformat = FALSE )  shapirores #>                Variable p_shapiro  Normality #> bill_len       bill_len   <0.001* Non-normal #> bill_dep       bill_dep   <0.001* Non-normal #> flipper_len flipper_len   <0.001* Non-normal #> body_mass     body_mass   <0.001* Non-normal #> year               year   <0.001* Non-normal

code: # First we would evaluate homoscedasticity car::leveneTest(   dat$bill_len,    group = dat$sex,   center = "median" ) #> Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = "median") #>        Df F value  Pr(>F)   #> group   1  2.8244 0.09378 . #>       331                   #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  # Then we apply the t test t.test(dat$bill_len) #>  #>  One Sample t-test #>  #> data:  dat$bill_len #> t = 148.78, df = 341, p-value < 2.2e-16 #> alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  43.34125 44.50261 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x  #>  43.92193 continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex" ) continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex",   flextableformat = FALSE ) #>      Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Levene P_T_Test Var_Equal P_Mann_Whitney #> 1    bill_len         <0.001*  0.09378  <0.001*      TRUE        <0.001* #> 2    bill_dep         <0.001*  0.68955  <0.001*      TRUE        <0.001* #> 3 flipper_len         <0.001*  0.04011  <0.001*     FALSE        <0.001* #> 4   body_mass         <0.001*  0.01435  <0.001*     FALSE        <0.001* #> 5        year         <0.001*  0.99834  0.99323      TRUE        0.99373 #>   Diff_Means   CI_Lower   CI_Upper Significant_test #> 1   -3.75779   -4.86656   -2.64903    Mann-W-U test #> 2   -1.46562   -1.86021   -1.07103    Mann-W-U test #> 3   -7.14232  -10.06481   -4.21982    Mann-W-U test #> 4 -683.41180 -840.57826 -526.24533    Mann-W-U test #> 5    0.00076   -0.17478    0.17630             None library(table1) #>  #> Attaching package: 'table1' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     units, units<-  table1::label(dat$sex)        <- "Sex" table1::label(dat$bill_len)   <- "Bill length" table1::label(dat$bill_dep)   <- "Bill depth" continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex" ) continuous_2g(   data = dat,   groupvar = "sex",   caption = TRUE )

title: Using BiVariAn
text: next step create graphical representations. , want use ggplot2 write separate code every plot (implies multiple lines code can become tedious want extensive customization). Let us create boxplot represent comparison flipper_len across sex variable.  Repeating every variable implies multiple lines code. reason, auto_bp_cont function can help streamline workflow. simply call function store output object. object list, can select specific plot want display include report.  remember, previously assigned labels using table1::label(). good news labels can also used plots.  point everything need build report.
code: library(tidyr) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) dat_comp <- dat %>%    drop_na(sex) # We remove the NAs from the sex variable  ggplot(   data = dat_comp,   mapping = aes(     x = sex,     y = flipper_len   ) ) +    geom_boxplot() +    labs(     x = "Sex",     y = "Flipper length"   ) +    theme_classic() graphs <- auto_bp_cont(   data = dat_comp,    groupvar = "sex" )  graphs$flipper_len table1::label(dat_comp$sex)         <- "Sex" table1::label(dat_comp$flipper_len) <- "Flipper length"  graphs <- auto_bp_cont(   data = dat_comp,    groupvar = "sex" )  graphs$flipper_len

title: Using BiVariAn
text: special mention, useful helper functions regression analysis. example, step_bw_p function helps tedious iterative process simplifying regression models stepwise backward selection based p value threshold, step_bw_firth function performs process models fitted logistf::logistf(). fit model dataset, obtain something like : practice, removes need manually perform three backward selection steps (otherwise require typing full model time using helpers reformulate). can also store output object:
code: model_reg <- glm(   sex ~ species + island + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass,    data = dat,    family = binomial() )  step_bw_p(model_reg) #>  #> Initial model: sex ~ species + island + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass  #> Analysis of Deviance Table (Type II tests) #>  #> Response: sex #>             LR Chisq Df Pr(>Chisq)     #> species       32.685  2  7.991e-08 *** #> island         1.061  2     0.5882     #> bill_len      32.923  1  9.588e-09 *** #> bill_dep      35.316  1  2.803e-09 *** #> flipper_len    0.304  1     0.5815     #> body_mass     50.238  1  1.362e-12 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Removing island (p = 0.5882) #> Analysis of Deviance Table (Type II tests) #>  #> Response: sex #>             LR Chisq Df Pr(>Chisq)     #> species       31.895  2  1.186e-07 *** #> bill_len      33.097  1  8.769e-09 *** #> bill_dep      34.748  1  3.752e-09 *** #> flipper_len    0.189  1     0.6638     #> body_mass     51.667  1  6.575e-13 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Removing flipper_len (p = 0.6638) #> Analysis of Deviance Table (Type II tests) #>  #> Response: sex #>           LR Chisq Df Pr(>Chisq)     #> species     32.590  2  8.378e-08 *** #> bill_len    33.727  1  6.343e-09 *** #> bill_dep    36.486  1  1.538e-09 *** #> body_mass   58.852  1  1.700e-14 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> No eliminable terms above p_threshold. Stopping. #> $final_model #>  #> Call:  glm(formula = sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + body_mass,  #>     family = binomial(), data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #>      (Intercept)  speciesChinstrap     speciesGentoo          bill_len   #>       -76.093935         -6.897694         -7.875212          0.620082   #>         bill_dep         body_mass   #>         1.643613          0.005962   #>  #> Degrees of Freedom: 332 Total (i.e. Null);  327 Residual #>   (11 observations deleted due to missingness) #> Null Deviance:       461.6  #> Residual Deviance: 127.3     AIC: 139.3 #>  #> $steps #>            Step #> 1       Initial #> 2      - island #> 3 - flipper_len #>                                                                    Formula #> 1 "sex ~ species + island + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass" #> 2          "sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass" #> 3                        "sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + body_mass" #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "step_bw" step_res <- step_bw_p(   model_reg,    trace = FALSE # To avoid printing the process in the console )  step_res$steps       # Data frame of the steps involved #>            Step #> 1       Initial #> 2      - island #> 3 - flipper_len #>                                                                    Formula #> 1 "sex ~ species + island + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass" #> 2          "sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + flipper_len + body_mass" #> 3                        "sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + body_mass" step_res$final_model # Final model after all iterations #>  #> Call:  glm(formula = sex ~ species + bill_len + bill_dep + body_mass,  #>     family = binomial(), data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #>      (Intercept)  speciesChinstrap     speciesGentoo          bill_len   #>       -76.093935         -6.897694         -7.875212          0.620082   #>         bill_dep         body_mass   #>         1.643613          0.005962   #>  #> Degrees of Freedom: 332 Total (i.e. Null); title: Bivariate Automatic Analysis
text: purpose ‘BiVariAn’ facilitate bivariate analysis integrating functions allow results analyses represented graphically text. Currently package can generate summary tables analysis data : Analysis continuous variables across two groups using Student’s t-tests (Welch’s t-tests according homogeneity variances), Mann-Whitney U; analysis dichotomous variables using Chi-square Fisher’s exact test; analysis normality raw data using Shapiro-Wilk test. also possible generate graphs automatically without labels variables possibility choosing theme ‘ggplot2’ package. Currently development option generate generic interpretation statistical tests, temporarily available Spanish, plans include languages. addition bivariate analyses, regression analyses predictor selection using stepwise backward method linear, logistic Firth penalized logistic regression models can performed automated manner. Note: use package replace individual customized analysis, rather streamlines process producing results. encourage users perform statistical analyses based recommendations type study.

title: Bivariate Automatic Analysis
text: can install development version BiVariAn GitHub : can install official CRAN version :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("AndresFloresG/BiVariAn") install.packages("BiVariAn")

title: Bivariate Automatic Analysis
text: Loading package Render automatic Shapiro-Wilk’s table simple dataset  Return Shapiro-Wilk’s results dataframe Render automatic Shapiro-Wilk’s table complex dataset shapiro.test, sample size must 3 5000 Let’s select 300 observations (arbitrary) Now, let’s select specific columns database  Common use shapiro.test Return Shapiro-Wilk’s results dataframe
code: library(BiVariAn) auto_shapiro_raw(cars) shapiro.test(cars$speed) #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  cars$speed #> W = 0.97765, p-value = 0.4576 auto_shapiro_raw(cars, flextableformat = FALSE) #>       Variable p_shapiro  Normality #> speed    speed   0.45763     Normal #> dist      dist    0.0391 Non-normal # Load riskCommunicator to access Framingham dataset library(riskCommunicator) # Load dplyr to select specific columns library(dplyr) data(cvdd) set.seed(081224) ex_sample<-slice_sample(cvdd, n=300) auto_shapiro_raw(ex_sample %>% select(TOTCHOL, SYSBP, DIABP, BMI, HEARTRTE)) shapiro.test(ex_sample$TOTCHOL) #>  #>  Shapiro-Wilk normality test #>  #> data:  ex_sample$TOTCHOL #> W = 0.98654, p-value = 0.007891 auto_shapiro_raw(ex_sample %>% select(TOTCHOL, SYSBP, DIABP, BMI, HEARTRTE), flextableformat = FALSE) #>          Variable p_shapiro  Normality #> TOTCHOL   TOTCHOL   0.00789 Non-normal #> SYSBP       SYSBP   <0.001* Non-normal #> DIABP       DIABP   <0.001* Non-normal #> BMI           BMI   <0.001* Non-normal #> HEARTRTE HEARTRTE   <0.001* Non-normal

title: BiVariAn: Bivariate Automatic Analysis — BiVariAn-package
text: Simplify bivariate regression analyses automating result generation, including summary tables, statistical tests, customizable graphs. supports tests continuous dichotomous data, well stepwise regression linear, logistic, Firth penalized logistic models. substitute tailored analysis, 'BiVariAn' accelerates workflows expanding features like multilingual interpretations results.methods selecting significant statistical tests, well predictor selection prediction functions, can referenced works Marc Kery (2003) doi:10.1890/0012-9623(2003)84[92:NORDIG]2.0.CO;2  Rainer Puhr (2017) doi:10.1002/sim.7273 .

what: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
title: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
text: Automatically generates barplot stratified group variables without percentages.

title: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
code: auto_bar_categ(   data,   groupvar = NULL,   bar_args = NULL,   theme_func = theme_serene,   lang_labs = NULL,   showpercent = TRUE,   drop_na = TRUE )

title: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
text: data Name dataframe groupvar Name grouping variable. Grouping variable used "fill" aesthetics argument creation ggplot object. provided, function take variable grouping display "fill" legend. bar_args List arguments passed "geom_bar". NULL, function uses default arguments : position = "dodge" colour = "black" linewidth = 0.9 alpha = 0.5 theme_func Theme generated plots. Must name function without parenthesis. Use example: theme_minimal instead theme_minimal() lang_labs Language displayed labels. null, default spanish. showpercent Logical atribute indicate graph include percentages drop_na Remove NAs provided dataframe

title: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
text: Returns list containing barplots ggplot object. Can accessed via $ operator

title: Automatic generation of barplot with percentages — auto_bar_categ
code: data<-data.frame(categ = rep(letters[1:2], 10), var1 = rep(LETTERS[4:5], 10), var2 = rep(LETTERS[6:7], 10), var3 = rep(LETTERS[8:9], 10), var4 = rep(LETTERS[10:11], 10))  data$categ <- as.factor(data$categ) data$var1 <- as.factor(data$var1) data$var2 <- as.factor(data$var2) data$var3 <- as.factor(data$var3) data$var4 <- as.factor(data$var4)  barplot_list<-auto_bar_categ(data = data, groupvar = "categ", lang_labs = "EN")  barplot_list$var1    # Example using `groupvar` argument as `NULL` auto_bar_categ(data = data)$var2

code: auto_bar_cont(   data,   groupvar,   err_bar_show = TRUE,   err_bar = c("sd", "se"),   col_args = list(),   lang_labs = c("EN", "SPA"),   theme_func = theme_serene )

title: Automatic barplot of continous variables — auto_bar_cont
text: data Name dataframe groupvar Grouping variable err_bar_show Logical indicator. Default TRUE show error bars columns. Default TRUE err_bar Statistic shown error bar. Can "sd" standard deviation "se" standard error. Defauult "se". col_args Arguments passed geom_col inside function. Default arguments : fill="grey" color = "black" alpha = 0.8 lang_labs Language resulting plots. Can "EN" english "SPA" spanish. Default "SPA" theme_func Theme generated plots. Must name function without parenthesis. Use example: theme_minimal instead theme_minimal()

code: # example code  data <- data.frame(group = rep(letters[1:2], 15), var1 = rnorm(30, mean = 15, sd = 5), var2 = rnorm(30, mean = 20, sd = 2), var3 = rnorm(30, mean = 10, sd = 1), var4 = rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd =2))  data$group<-as.factor(data$group)  continuous_corr_test(data = data, referencevar = "var1", flextableformat = FALSE) #>   Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Pearson P_Spearman P_Kendall   r_Pearson #> 1     var2         0.73407   0.62153    0.58669   0.69717 -0.09392483 #> 2     var3         0.38925   0.19774    0.14690   0.10877  0.24192812 #> 3     var4         0.22638   0.68118    0.39157   0.47876  0.07821939 #>     r_P_CI_L  r_P_CI_H   t_Kendall    t_K_CI_L  t_K_CI_H rho_Spearman #> 1 -0.4393280 0.2756727 -0.05287356 -0.29431440 0.1885673   -0.1030033 #> 2 -0.1296405 0.5539182  0.20919540 -0.06226355 0.4806544    0.2711902 #> 3 -0.2902285 0.4264707  0.09425287 -0.18977795 0.3782837    0.1617353 #>    rho_S_CI_L rho_S_CI_H #> 1 -0.44669614  0.2671807 #> 2 -0.09872455  0.5752561 #> 3 -0.21081795  0.4932629  # Set names to variables if(requireNamespace("table1")){ table1::label(data$var2) <- "Variable 2" table1::label(data$var3) <- "Variable 3" table1::label(data$var4) <- "Variable 4"  continuous_corr_test(data = data, referencevar = "var1", flextableformat = FALSE) } #>     Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Pearson P_Spearman P_Kendall   r_Pearson #> 1 Variable 2         0.73407   0.62153    0.58669   0.69717 -0.09392483 #> 2 Variable 3         0.38925   0.19774    0.14690   0.10877  0.24192812 #> 3 Variable 4         0.22638   0.68118    0.39157   0.47876  0.07821939 #>     r_P_CI_L  r_P_CI_H   t_Kendall    t_K_CI_L  t_K_CI_H rho_Spearman #> 1 -0.4393280 0.2756727 -0.05287356 -0.29431440 0.1885673   -0.1030033 #> 2 -0.1296405 0.5539182  0.20919540 -0.06226355 0.4806544    0.2711902 #> 3 -0.2902285 0.4264707  0.09425287 -0.18977795 0.3782837    0.1617353 #>    rho_S_CI_L rho_S_CI_H #> 1 -0.44669614  0.2671807 #> 2 -0.09872455  0.5752561 #> 3 -0.21081795  0.4932629  # Example performing correlation test for only one variable if(requireNamespace("dplyr")){ library(dplyr) continuous_corr_test(data = data %>% select("var1","var2"),  referencevar = "var1", flextableformat = FALSE, corr_test = "pearson") } #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #>     Variable P_Shapiro_Resid P_Pearson   r_Pearson  r_P_CI_L  r_P_CI_H #> 1 Variable 2         0.73407   0.62153 -0.09392483 -0.439328 0.2756727  # code: if (requireNamespace("logistf", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(logistf)   data <- mtcars   data$am <- as.factor(data$am)   regression_model <- logistf(am ~ mpg + cyl + disp, data = data)   # Perform backward stepwise, forcing 'cyl' to remain   stepwise <- step_bw_firth(     regression_model,     forced = c("cyl"),     p_threshold = 0.05,     trace = FALSE   )   final_model <- stepwise$final_model   # Show steps and summary   stepwise$steps   summary(final_model) } #> logistf::logistf(formula = new_formula, data = dataprov) #>  #> Model fitted by Penalized ML #> Coefficients: #>                   coef  se(coef) lower 0.95    upper 0.95     Chisq          p #> (Intercept)  0.8201147 1.8232397 -2.8921363  4.6412094266 0.1928272 0.66057392 #> cyl          0.5694572 0.6299805 -0.6794237  2.0101418441 0.7491163 0.38675617 #> disp        -0.0221055 0.0120472 -0.0526668 -0.0004207133 4.0277557 0.04475744 #>             method #> (Intercept)      2 #> cyl              2 #> disp             2 #>  #> Method: 1-Wald, 2-Profile penalized log-likelihood, 3-None #>  #> Likelihood ratio test=12.26211 on 2 df, p=0.002174283, n=32 #> Wald test = 7.246462 on 2 df, p = 0.02669628
